importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Subramanyam 'Subu' Vedam was sentenced to a two-and-a-half to five-year drug sentence in 1984 as part of a plea agreement, which was served concurrently with his life sentence for murder.
A deportation order was issued against Subramanyam Vedam in 1988 based on his murder and drug convictions, which remains a legal hurdle even after his exoneration of the murder charge.
The article was published on October 18, 2025, reporting on the current situation of Subramanyam Vedam's deportation proceedings following his exoneration and arrest by ICE.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: This period marks the time when Vedam received a separate drug-related sentence, which was served simultaneously with his life sentence for murder, and when the legal basis for his immigration status was established.
This timeframe includes the issuance of a formal deportation order against Vedam, which remains in effect despite his exoneration of the murder charge.
This period is currently relevant as Vedam is being detained and faces deportation proceedings in 2025, following the recent exonerations and the legal challenges to ICE's action.

keyTakeAways: Subramanyam 'Subu' Vedam was wrongfully imprisoned for over 40 years for a murder he did not commit.
New evidence exonerated Vedam of the murder of Tom Kinser, a 19-year-old college student, in a case where no physical evidence tied him to the crime.
Vedam was convicted in 1984 of murder and received a concurrent drug sentence, with the murder conviction later being overturned due to new evidence.
Despite being exonerated of the murder charge, Vedam is still subject to a 1988 deportation order due to his drug conviction.
ICE has detained Vedam and seeks to deport him to India, a country he has not lived in since infancy, despite weak familial and community ties.
Vedam's legal team and family are challenging the deportation order, arguing that his decades of good behavior, community service, and education should be considered.
The family believes the deportation represents another injustice, especially since Vedam has been cleared of the murder and is now a free man.
The case highlights systemic flaws in how immigration enforcement interacts with wrongful convictions and the lack of consideration for rehabilitation and reintegration.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Subramanyam 'Subu' Vedam, a legal permanent resident from India who moved to the U.S. at nine months old, was wrongfully imprisoned for over 40 years for the murder of his former roommate, Tom Kinser, a 19-year-old college student, with no physical evidence linking him to the crime. After being exonerated in early 2025, Vedam was arrested by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), who seeks to deport him to India â€” a country he has not lived in since infancy. Despite his innocence and decades of good behavior, community service, and education, the deportation order based on a 1988 conviction for a drug offense remains in effect. His family and legal team are challenging the deportation, arguing that his strong ties to the U.S. and rehabilitation should be recognized, and that sending him to a distant country with few connections constitutes another profound injustice. This case underscores the need for reform in how immigration enforcement handles individuals who have been wrongfully convicted and rehabilitated.
title: Wrongfully imprisoned for more than 40 years, Pennsylvania man now faces deportation by ICE
